title: How to become a better writer in 2019 - Quora

response.answer_text: So, you want to become a better writer in 2019. That’s great. You’ve come to the right place. Quora is like a training camp for aspiring writers.  ** For inspiration you might want to keep an image of your favorite writer close at hand. Hemingway inspires me. The best I can do to help you is to tell you what helped me to become a better writer. This is free advice, so take it for what it is worth. Seriously though, give these tips a fair trial and you will become a better writer. Realize that the only way to improve your writing, is by writing. You learn by doing. You don’t have to start out by trying to write the great American novel, just write something. Anything.Use Quora as a sounding board. You’ll get some good feedback here from some very talented individuals. We are fortunate to have an audience here. Take advantage of it.Write every day. Even if you don’t feel like it. Especially if you don’t feel like it. Answer three or four questions on Quora. Length isn’t important in your answer. Quality is.If you don’t like any of the questions you see here, write your own question and answer it.Write about what you know about and what you are passionate about.Read content from Top Writers. Read content from people who are not Top Writers. What is the difference (if any)?Daily read at least twice as much as you write.Your surroundings matter. Know what environment you write best in. It is usually best to avoid as many distractions as possible. I have to write with headphones and the sound of rain acting as a white noise.Everything you write has to have a beginning, a middle and an end. Break it into parts. Remember, people have short attention spans these days. Let your reader digest small chunks of information at a time.Remember the immortal words of Ernest Hemingway, “The first draft of anything is crap”. A good piece of writing is the result of lots of re-reading and editing. Sometimes you’ll spend as much time editing as you did writing in the first place.Read your work out loud as part of the writing and editing process. How does it hit your ear? If it sounds bad, change it.Write because you love to write. After all, this is going to be taking up a fair amount of your free time.Don’t write for the approval of others, or with the goal of gaining more followers or upvotes. For the love of God don’t write with the hopes of making money from this one day. If you are a good enough writer, people will come to you because you offer a quality product and maybe they’ll even ask if they can publish your work.Important point: Stop a writing session when you stop writing well. For example, I can tell when my work is starting to suck and I’m just “phoning it in”. When that happens, take a break, clear your head and get back at it. You may only need ten minutes, you may need to sleep on it. All depends.To reiterate: Write, read, recite, edit, repeat. Keep at it, I look forward to hearing what you have to say.

The ‘Result’ what they enjoy, the ‘Process’ what you should enjoy ~ Anonymous writer What is actually meant to being a writer? Anyone who writes, is a writer? Or be an ability to write a scrap blog, or article or book that can publish and acclaim a great fame and money? Maybe, Nothing actually meant to be a writer. Well…Unfurled the real concept of what should mean to be a writer is more easy to say than to write on it. What I'm doing is worthy enough to call myself a writer. Probably Yes or probably No. However, Without any sense of self-doubt or fear of not getting enough upvotes, I still writing this answer like this is only thing I really want to do. What I consider the important features as a writer are some of following abilities which makes a person - A writer. He writes not for the sake of fame, publicity, or money but for himself. Yup…these are byproducts of writing and should be embraced by a writer. But, the real purpose of writing is to pen down the feeling and thoughts.No matter if someone is appreciating your writings or not, you have been got upvotes on Quora or not and you have no clue what you are doing. Instead you are writing continuously, weaving the words obsessively. You have a feature to be a writer. How can you improve your writing skills? Write everyday as this is only thing you want to do in your past timeDon't be a guy with stagnant mind. Always try to be as creative as you can.Don’t be lazy; do your best to avoid procrastination.Stay focused! Distraction is the enemy of all great art.Stop worrying about being a good writer; just write.Forget about fame. write what is worthy.Don't think about perfection. Perfection is subjective. Each and every one has own interpretation. Just write as you wish.Don't write for publication.Write with conviction.Read. As much as you can.Writing isn't about making money, getting famous, getting dates, getting laid, or making friends. In the end, it's about enriching the lives of those who will read your work, and enriching your own life, as well. It's about getting up, getting well, and getting over. Getting happy, okay? Getting happy. ~ Stephen king Have a good day!!

I make a living by writing. More specifically, by ghostwriting. Every single day I need to sit down, listen to my clients, and put their thoughts on paper with a spin. That means I’m expected to look for different angles on how to make their ideas pop up to draw the reader in without losing their ‘voice’ in the process. So… I don’t have the luxury of getting stale on my writing journey. Either I write better each day, or I don’t eat. Now, I’m no guru in this subject by any stretch of the mark. I’m still struggling to find my voice ever since I first began writing in Quora in 2017. However, as I began to transition from the former to working under Martí Sánchez at Influence Podium, I have come up with different ways to keep learning. Here are 6 of them: 1. Choose one single type of writing style and commit to it before moving onto the next There are many different styles of writing. There’s fiction writers, non-fiction writers, research writers, copywriters, creative copywriters, academic writers, ad nauseam. Each one of these has a different set of guidelines to pull them off effectively. You can’t just transition from writing like Stephen King to someone like Gary Harbert and correctly pull it off. You’re better off sticking to one until you’re great in that domain - like ‘I can write for someone and ask them for big bucks in return’ kinda great. Only then you’re free to make the switch. 2. Read a lot from those who are great in the field you’re writing for It’s common knowledge that to become a great writer you need to form a reading habit. But it’s not so simple as to read whatever comes across you. I won’t get better at writing for entrepreneurs and business owners by reading from Hemingway or Tolkien. Instead, I’d have to take a look at what people like Nicolas Cole have published over the years in their careers. It isn’t wrong to read from great authors to gain new ideas or pass the time. It’s wrong to read from great authors when you’re purposely trying to become better at something entirely different. 3. Make it a routine that you can stick to for longer than a year The more time you invest in consistently practicing your writing, the more likely you’ll become better. If such’s the case, why don’t you design a system for consistently making it to the desk to write something, one that you can see yourself committing to for a year? In his book The War of Art, Steven Pressfield states: “The most important thing about art is to work. Nothing else matters except sitting down every day and trying.” 4. Exercise your creativity by coming up with 10 ideas each day - by James Altucher Your writing process will benefit from a creative mind. Problem is many tend to think of creativity as something that flows through your hands and never stays put for enough time to catch it. But that’s the wrong angle to look at it. The creative process is just another symptom of your mind connecting various ideas to form something new. And as such, you can get better at it by practicing. Just as if you want to grow your biceps by consistently hitting the required reps, you want to write down 10 ideas each idea to make your mind better at being creative. 10 ideas/day = 3,650 ideas/year. 5. Take a walk in-between long sessions of writing and quietly appreciate what’s happening around you There’s the writer’s block that happens when you don’t write often. Then there’s the writer’s block that happens when you’ve written for over three hours straight without looking away from the screen. Your mind needs time to catch up when it has extensively focused on something. The best thing you can do for this is to take a walk outside. Don’t look for your phone, don’t look for anything that gives your brain a similar stimulus as your phone. Just go for a walk and let your thoughts drift as you look at things. Then come back after half-an-hour, sit down, and write some more. 6. Read what you wrote yesterday out loud When I started ghostwriting, I struggled with making my client’s voice resonate through the words. That happened because I had grown accustomed to writing for myself for over a year each day, and so I’d fall back in the habit of using my voice instead of their’s. One mentor in particular had a different answer from what I expected to my struggles. I gave him some of the stuff I was working on and explained the issue, and he just asked, “Have you tried reading out loud what you put in the paper?” Your mind tends to perceive your writing as better than it actually is. Reading out loud takes you away from your thoughts, and forces you to catch the clutter, the fluff, and anything that sounds funky.  Like this answer? Follow me on Quora to make sure you never miss out on content like this. I strive to publish each day!

To be a better writer for a dad, a husband, and a full time engineer is quite difficult ambition due to the lack of the quality time. However, I can make some specific steps to become a better writer in 2019. Among others the below mentioned actions can help me to be a better craftsman in the next year. Right now, I am in a 30 days writing challenge at Quora. I will write 30 answers in December. I make the conclusion at the end of this year, and probably I continue. Daily writing should be a habit for me.I would like to learn sales copywriting. Sales is a quite difficult task, but sales in print can be more difficult. If a salesman made a mistake, than only the possible buyer will notice that. If a copywriter makes mistake than thousand of people can feel the effect. Advertisement reach a lot of people. Wrong ads result low sales. I will read books about copywriting and make some baby steps in the practice.I am not a native English speaker. My grammar and literacy should be improved. I do online refresher courses on English language.I finish read the fantasy series A Song of Ice and Fire from George R.R. Martin. I read the series for some years now. I never read two books next each other. I make always a brake. However, I like to see the result of the consistency and persistence. I read those books mostly during the daily commute. Days are passed and pages are read. Books are finished. The reading result reminds me, that small steps added together. Good to see as a busy parent.Networking with writers. We learn and support each other. Quality writings around the globe improve the mental health of the humanity. Time is value, do not waste your time on bad content.

Thanks for the A2A. The man on top of the mountain didn’t just fall there. He got there one step at a time. Things take time. If you wanted to fly a plane, what would you do? You'd find a ground school and take lessons. If you wanted to play the piano, what would you do? You'd find a piano teacher and take classes. What makes writing any different? Writing is an art, but it’s a learned art. To ask someone how to write a story is like asking “How do I climb a mountain?” You don’t, unless you’ve had the training. And no, it’s not rocket science, but writing is something that needs to be studied and practiced. Anybody can sit down and write crap. You see it all the time in self pubbed books. Most people will tell you to just start writing, and keep writing, but I don't agree. It's not enough to just write every day if you don't know what you're doing or how to improve something. That just means days and weeks and months of useless writing. It's like not knowing how to knit so you just keep making loops with the yarn. You can't get better, you can't turn that into a scarf ... you have the desire, but you don't know how. I'm going to give you my stock answer that I give everyone who asks me this question. I'm going to give you some good advice on how to learn the craft, and give you a place to send in some of your work when you're ready. In order to write stories that people want to read you will need to understand how to put one together. There is a definite pattern and rhythm to it. And there are certain expectations from the editors and publishing houses as to how your story is laid out. You will need a good imagination, one that can look at a situation and picture all sorts of different scenarios. You need to be able to ask 'what if' and come up with twists and lines that are new and fresh. You will need to be able to research things. For example I wrote a story set in Iran where there was a wedding. I had to research how the wedding would take place, the food, the customs, common Iranian names, clothing, etc. in order to write an interesting yet correct story. Take classes in writing; grammar and punctuation (very important... lots of self published books are swimming in glaring errors and typos), character building, dialogue, plotting, pacing, point of view (POV), inner and outer conflicts, subplots, scenes and sequels, genres, story boards, twists, chapter hooks, suspense, killer opening lines, and satisfying endings. If you're going to write sci-fi you will need to take classes in world building. Each genre of book has its own set of expectations from the reader that you will need to fulfill. For example a murder mystery must have clues for the reader to try and solve. A romance needs a happen ever after ending, known to writers as an HEA. A thriller needs fast pacing and danger. There are classes in short story writing. Where to find these classes? Local community colleges often offer writing classes. My local library has classes seasonally. Best of all there are hundreds of classes you can take on-line. They run about $25-$35 each and range from 2 to 4 weeks. Google on-line writing classes and you will get lots of sites. Try www.oirwa.com or www.savvyauthors.com. They have classes year round. You don’t have to join either one but if you do you get a discount on their classes. Just because a class might be about writing romances, writing is writing; many of the same principles apply to other genres. So don’t hesitate to take a course on character building or writing scenes just because the site caters to romance. There are sites that offer expensive classes, so be careful. I’d recommend starting with a few less expensive ones to see if you really like writing and want to continue. IMO it is not necessary to have a degree or to take an expensive course to write well. Read a lot. Get a feel for how a story is told; how it starts, how it progresses through the story to a satisfying end. See how your favorite author keeps you interested. I don't know your age, but when you are able join some writing groups, even online groups are helpful. Oftentimes these groups offer lectures and classes in writing. They share their work and critique each other. Once you start taking classes and get a good feel for how to put a story together, write some short stories (800 - 1500 words). The more you write, the better you will become. You will make new writer mistakes, we all did. But that's how you learn. I say start with short stories because they are, well short, and don't take years to complete like a novel does. You can share your stories with others and get feedback. Take the feedback and use what you feel is constructive for you and ignore the others. Some people don't give good feedback, or there is a motive behind their negative comments. You have to learn which ones to take and learn from and which ones to disregard. And when you are reading and critiquing other's stories, be kind, give good feedback, and find something positive to say to them. It's hard to hear harsh things about your writing. It's tough love. But it works when you get it and understand why the comment was made and you go and make your piece better because of it. Submitting to contests is another way to get good feedback because the judges are usually editors and agents who have their finger on the pulse of good writing that sells. Once you feel you have written a great short story, be brave and submit it to a magazine that publishes fiction in the genre you wrote. Don't worry about rejections. They will come. Oftentimes it's not because your story is not good, it's because the story doesn't fit their needs. They are running a business after all, and they pick the stories that they feel will best entertain their readers. All authors get rejections. It's part of the 'hunt'. Here’s a place to start submitting. Check out their guidelines carefully. FLASH FICTION ONLINE http://flashfictiononline.com/main/submission-guidelines/ We publish stories from 500 to 1,000 words in length. They’re very short, but they are still stories. That means the best ones have strong, interesting characters, plots, and (to some extent, at least) settings. We’re not that concerned about genre. Many of us have a fondness for science fiction and fantasy, but we also like literary fiction; and in any case, great flash stories aren’t always easily classified. If you wrote it, and you love it, then submit it. No erotica, porn, graphic sex, or violence. Pays $60 per story. Buys reprints at two cents/word. (I checked this site on 10/12/18 and it’s still operating and the details are correct.) Once you are good enough to sell a few short stories, then you will have the skills to think about plotting out a whole book. Check out my e-book for more writing tips: Write Better Right Now: Creative Writing Tips http://amzn.com/B00IHIWUDC Only $1.99.

There is an old saying about being a writer that still rings as true today as it did when it was first said, perhaps hundreds of years ago. The saying goes “The best way to be a better writer is to write”. As simple as it sounds, writing is the best way to get better at writing. There is also the added help of reading. The word is the more you read, the better you will understand how to write. I have been told you should read good writing, bad writing, and in fact all writing. The above being said, in addition to writing, you can also do several things to help improve your writing skills. You can join a writer’s group and learn from others as well as share input and get feedback on your writing. You can also take online classes. Several organizations offer free, cheap and even credit-based online classes for writing. If you have never taken English Composition I and II, then start there and get some college credits while you learn. If you already have a degree or do not wish to spend money at this time, there are hundreds of free classes online you can take and learn more about writing. Finally, consider how you write or at least how you complete your writing for publication. While you may use a notebook, a tablet or even a phone, nothing beats a good grammar review or software that review your writing for you. You can use anything as basic as Word and even add in grammar review programs to monitor as you write. The bottom line, even with groups, software, and study, the best way is still that age-old saying, just write. If you want to improve, just like anything, practice will help you improve.

You become a better writer by writing. It’s a skill that requires nuturing, through consistent practice, acclimation, and learning from one’s mistakes. It’s one of those “use it or lose it” skills. I’ve had “Writer” next to my name as a job title for 15 years now, and I still don’t have it all figured out. Being a lifelong learner by using your brain as a sponge helps. What also helps is reading. Read what the pros write. Find good writers and read everything they put out. Don’t try to read it all, because you can’t. Just read. My high school English teacher said you become a better writer by becoming a better reader. Nothing about improving one’s writing is more true. As with learning any skill, there’s some trial and error involved. Architects desigining houses don’t always draw up winners. I’ve always equated the writing process with building a house. Do it one step at a time, and the finished product will be something you’ll be proud of. And you don’t have to build a mansion every time. Eventually, others will be reading what you write and learning from you.

In 30 seconds, I'll show you how to become a better writer in 30 days or less. Write 3 answers per day. Each day, read one simple writing tip. No more than one. Implement that tip into the 3 answers you write. After writing those 3 answers, go back and reread the 3 answers from the previous day. Read the answers out loud. You’ll catch things that sound funky. Look for ways to promote clarity. To reduce clutter and fluff. To punch the answers up. Rereading old answers is just as important as writing new answers, perhaps more so. I edit the living hell out of my answers. It is the true path to better writing. Write 3. Re-read 3. Learn 1. Edit. Edit. Edit. You'll get better at writing, you'll get more views, more upvotes and more followers. Hope this was helpful. Good luck and Godspeed.

Now Sean, how in the world can anyone answer this? We don’t know how good you are today. Since I don’t know the answer to “how good is Sean?” I have one suggestion: you know where your weaknesses are. You know where you need improvement. And if you don’t, try this: what do you avoid working on? That’s where you’ll be weakest and that’s where you need practice. You didn’t think anyone would say, “just keep doing what you’re doing,” did you? You only get to do the most fun writing after you tackle the stuff you know isn’t as great. Although I’m a lifelong member of the “Eat Dessert First” (© 2017, D.K. Carlen. All rights reserved. Write for permission to re-use.) school of thought, this time I’m going to say that you can’t write where you’re strong until you tackle one area of lesser strength every day. At the end of 2019 you can splurge, buy the newest a new copy of Chicago Manual of Style, eat dessert first, and know that you improved your writing all year.

I’m answering this question on November 9, 2018 and as of this moment the best way to become a better writer in 2019 is to write 500 words today. Then do it again tomorrow. There are 53 days left this year, including this one. See if you can write at least 500 words in every one. By the time 2019 rolls around, you’ll be in the habit of writing every day. Put as much of it as you can out in public as quickly as you can to get feedback. Pay attention to what works and what doesn’t and keep experimenting. If you write at least 500 words every day, you will write more than 182,500 words next year, the equivalent of more than two full books. But the way that it’s most likely to happen is if you write 500 words today. They don’t have to be good, they just have to get on the page.

The best thing you can do is establish a writing habit. It doesn't have to be every day, but make it regular. If you need a starting point, start by observing what's around you, right where you are, with all of your senses. But first, work out your when, where and why: When can you get some focus time? When are your energy levels right for writing (buoyant enough and not too tired)?Where's the best place for you to write? A cafe? In the spare room? In bed first thing in the morning?Why do you want to write? Knowing the specifics of why will help motivate you.Once you know your when, where and why, and you've got a regular writing habit going, you'll be able to figure out your what (what you want to write, and what you want to write about) and you'll be able to figure out how, by doing a bit of research, a bit of reading around your 'what'. In the meantime, keep turning up to write. I have a few writing courses up on Udemy. There are some coupon codes here. Good luck! P.S. I made a list of some of my favourite writing prompt books on Amazon for my students. In case it helps, here it is.

Thanks for A2A Lalita Choudhary “Close the door. Write with no one looking over your shoulder. Don’t try to figure out what other people want to hear from you; figure out what you have to say. It’s the one and only thing you have to offer.” ~ Barbara Kingsolver Well, I think there are steps for everything. You don’t start writing good in one go, it’ll be always a crap. A piece full of shit. The only thing that differs you from big writers is that they kept their shit in a file and wrote another and then another. It’s not they knew they were writing shit, but they thought that they were writing masterpiece. Then one day, after a long time, they reopened the first page written by them and found that it was just a pure form of shit. Nothing less. So, here are simple steps: Write everyday. 250 words, if not more.Keep your work safe. You’ll need it, trust me.Read.After one month, re-read your previous work. Laugh.Read.Write.Start it right now, why make it 1st january goal?*Simple*

Writing is like losing weight. Bear with me. If you want to lose weight, there are a hundred schemes and diets you can use to do so. You can sign up for services to bring you specially prepared food. You can cut out carbs entirely. You can only eat three blueberries for lunch and a banana for tea. If you’ve ever tried to diet, you probably know that people start these diets full of good intentions, and end them with a binge, having become hungry. We all know that the best way to diet (for a healthy person with no other medical conditions) is to have smaller portions of food and to eat more fruit and veg. It’s boring. There’s no fun, gimmicky club you can join. You just have to buy smaller plates and more carrots. If you want to write well, there are a hundred schemes and tips you can use to do so. People will tell you their own writing routine. Speed-writing 500 words for twenty minutes followed by an hour break. Writing between certain times of the day. Going back and rereading your work every few sentences. Writing with abandon. We all know that the best way to learn how to write well is to read more and write more. Read any interview with any published author and they will always tell you to read more. That the more you read and the more you write, the better you will get. But that’s dull. You want a quick trick to write better. READ MORE. WRITE MORE. I do not give a damn when you write or what on or what you read or where you read it. Get comfy, grab a book, read it. Consider what you thought was good about the writing, and what you thought could be improved. Then write and apply that new knowledge. It is not easy. There’s no way round it. Just do it.

Develop your own process for drafting, editing, publishing, and sharing your writing. Here’s an example of my process when I first started: 1. Write down a list of 10 topics that interest you (5 minutes) DesignEntrepreneurshipEducationCoworkingIdeasComicsDonutsFreelancingTravelWriting2. Turn these interests into questions (10 minutes) How do you bridge the gap between design and business?How do we make entrepreneurship more accessible?What will education look like in the future?Why is coworking becoming so popular?What is the first step in making ideas happen?What can design students learn from comics?Where can I find the best blueberry cake donut in St. Louis?What is the most important step when starting to freelance?How do I start traveling more?What is the easiest way to start writing?3. Do a little research in order to form an opinion for each topic (30 mins) 4. Answer each question in one sentence to create your BIG IDEA for each article (15 mins) In order to bridge the gap between design and business, schools need to teach business development skills to design students and design thinking skills to business students earlier on in their education.For entrepreneurship to be more accessible, entrepreneurs need to be connected to others who share their idea and have the skills they need.In the future of education, an apprentice/master relationship will reemerge to better address the individual learning of various skills needed in the new workforce.Coworking is becoming so popular because it provides a collaborative setting for the new workforce that balances productivity with camaraderie.The first step in making your idea happen is to share it with at least one other person in order to receive tangible feedback.Design students should look to comics as the perfect example for effective design, noticing their combination of narrative text and supportive imagery.After doing extensive research, the best blueberry cake donut in St. Louis can be found at Ex-Cop Donut Shop, and here is why…The most important step when starting to freelance is to successfully position yourself by identifying who you are, what you do, who you help, and what value you provide them.In order to start traveling more, try focusing on working remotely, whether through your company or on your own.The easiest way to start writing is to take action and follow this framework :)5. Expand on one of these answers in order to create your first draft (30 minutes) 6. Show that first draft to three people: Someone you know who writesSomeone you don’t know who writesSomeone who would be a target reader in that category7. Take feedback from all three people and revise your first draft (30 minutes) 8. Check for grammar and spelling (5 minutes) 9. Click “Publish” and get ready to share your article 10. Make sure to thank and respond to each person who leaves a comment on your article

10 steps to become a better writer 1. Write 2. Write more 3. Write more 4. Write even more 5. Write when you do not want to write 6. Write when you have to write 7. Write when you have something to say 8. Write when you have nothing to say 9. Write each day 10. Continue writing ... or more exactly ... Never stop writing ! What more, is it clear, right? As I often say, writing is a difficult art. But when you think about what musician, dancer, painter or sportsman does not spend hours perfecting himself. On Friday, January 31st, at the Bydgoszcz meeting in Poland, Frenchman Renaud Lavillenie broke the French pole vault record with a jump of 6.08m. Six days earlier, he had jumped 6.04 m. To reach this record, I heard that he was training hours every day in his garden.

Writers are not made, writers are formed. — Stephen King Everyone has a writer inside more or less. I believe many people out there have some talent at writing or storytelling. What differentiates a great writer from an amateur writer is that one make efforts to shape and sharpen the little talent one has. One does that by writing. Making mistakes and learning from it. Again and again!! That is how one becomes a master at writing. That is how they formed as a writer. So, this is what we all need who want to be a better writer. Go out there and make mistakes. Learn from it. Correct it. Repeat the process. Take your time to form yourself as a writer.

Some tips you might find useful.. Write more whatever in your mind on the word, it could also be a paper if you are easy with it.Reread your previously written content.Learn 5 new words daily. 5 words*30 days = 150 new words per monthLearn different writing styles like APA style etc.Business writing, Technical Writing, SEO based writing if you are working at some organization as a writer. This would help. Learn all of these step by step.Read more answers from Quora and other platforms and see how creative people are at writing great content.Research, Learn, Write, Edit & Repeat. This will help you become a better writer and most importantly, set a goal for 2019.

Here’s my fast and easy tip. Look at things twice. Here is a sentence that I was just writing in a novel I’m working on. Version 1: “Okay,” she says, looking at me with her sparkling blue eyes. I looked at it and thought, ‘that sucks’ Version 2 “Okay,” she says, blue eyes shining even in the dim light of the bar. Much better eh? Get it all out there in the first draft, but don’t be afraid to improve. Sometimes the first way is smashingly brilliant and that’s fine. Other times, not so much.

Just start writing which comes in your mind randomly,,,, Don't think too much about grammatical errors, sentence formation and spelling's mistakes. But always keep in mind you have to improve your self, day by day , answer by answer paragraph by paragraph line bye line and the last one is words by words. Now read your answer whatever you written and compare with your new answer I am sure if u really want to be a writer ,you would have been definitely improved. I don't want to be a writer but I want to improve my writing skills. Suggestions and edits are welcome. Dk..

you know,this is the thing which i have learnt from quora that people like beautiful answers.Beauty comes when you use more appropriate and meaningful words. people like it when you give a good example about the message which you want to convey. people like it when you are clear about a thought which you want to convey. people like it when they feel connected to your content. people like it when they can visualise or imagine your answer .It happens when you tell them a story and make them understood. and in the end,patience and practise make us a better writer.

By writing more and reading a LOT more. People think that by only writing they can get better. You need to read and understand how other writers do their writing and use what works for you! Learn how to edit better and delete parts from your article without complaining. This is IMPORTANT. Share your content on a consistent basis in order to know what people think of it! You may love your work but people may not and the idea is for your audience to like it.

Thanks Sean for a2a. Here are a few useful and helpful tips: By writing better than what we did in 2018;Use shorter sentences and one idea per paragraph, if possible;Working over having more followers;Not too long answers;Answers should carry generalized as well as specific information;Generate interest so that readers are captivating reading full text;Pick questions that are appropriate for answering in better way;Give analytical statement and/or personal opinion at the end.I hope that will work for us.

Define your goal more clearly. What does “better” mean to you? More prolific? More sagacious? And how do you measure this improvement? Once you have a clearly defined goal, develop the plan, the steps needed to achieve that goal. As you do so, you might identify obstacles that require other plans to address. Repeat as necessary. Evaluate your progress at set intervals, adjust plan or goal as needed.

Hoo Boy! I’ve done more writing courses than I can count. I no longer waste my $$. What are you trying to achieve? Improve your grammar? Basic structure? Fleshing out ideas? Construct the outline for a novel? If the latter, do you want to learn about plot-driven or character driven? It really depends on what your needs are at this time and what you want to write. Think that through first before you enroll in anything.

In this time many people write book ,article. But all writer didn't get success due to his containt If you writing any thing you must have deep knowledge of that topic /subject . Second most thing is way of writing , choose simple word in book/article so reader easily understand means book should be user friendly Third thing is your book should be unique - If you copy material of other book , then you never got success , Their is no shortcut in writing You get success from your own work . Best of luck

Short answer: write. Set a time and place, maybe set a timer and write. Doesn’t matter what you write unless you have a project you want to work on. Also, read. Not just what you prefer, but everything you can get your hands on, things you might not find all that interesting to begin with, but if you’re truly interested in being a writer, published or shared, read.

All of the other answers are good, but they don’t take into account the value of guidance. Try an internship. If it’s any good, the people offering it will be willing to offer constructive advice, and you can learn from their experiences. We’re offering one now at indieauthortimes,com, but I’m sure there are others. Look for one and get involved.

Thanks for the A2A. Aside from writing more and more for practice, you mean? Learn. You have two ears and two eyes but only one mouth. Listening and observing are more important that talking. The more experiences you open yourself up to and the more things you learn, the more things you will have to write about. Oh, and practice anyway. Then practice some more.

I assume you mean writing fiction. Go back to a short story or novel you enjoyed. Read it again. Forget the plot. Notice how the author used short and long sentences. Notice how dialog is handled. Write a short story using the ideas you learned from your study of your favorite author.

write simple, write like you talk, and know exactly who you’re writing for. you can talk like a lawyer or talk like a mechanic. if you can’t talk realistically in your own realm you shouldn’t be writing. write a gift, not an invoice for services rendered.

Keep writing for practice makes perfect. Travel and read a lot for as a writer you need more experience to be productive in thoughts. Attend writing workshops and the like to improve techniques. Talk to people …. gather ideas.

Keep putting pen to paper, or fingers to keyboard. Everyone develops writing ability by Doing it. If critique group members or professors see your work and advise improvements, don’t dismiss them out of hand. Make the changes.
The only way you will improve as a writer is to write. Look back at the stuff you’ve written in the past and rewrite/rethink it. Even in the past year, you’ll find places you can improve.
